segment.source: What are the choices when developing cross-platform apps?.
segment.target: What are the choices when developing cross-platform apps?.

segment.source: Selecting an approach to iOS and UWP app development
segment.target: Selecting an approach to iOS and UWP app development

segment.source: Selecting an approach to iOS and UWP app development
segment.target: Selecting an approach to iOS and UWP app development

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: What are the choices when developing cross-platform apps?
segment.target: What are the choices when developing cross-platform apps?

segment.source: What's the best way to support both iOS and Windows?
segment.target: What's the best way to support both iOS and Windows?

segment.source: Windows and iOS may seem to be very different beasts, but a growing number of tools and techniques can greatly assist you if you need to write apps that support both platforms (and Android too).
segment.target: Windows and iOS may seem to be very different beasts, but a growing number of tools and techniques can greatly assist you if you need to write apps that support both platforms (and Android too).

segment.source: The best solution depends on the type of app you are writing, and whether you are starting from scratch or porting an existing project.
segment.target: The best solution depends on the type of app you are writing, and whether you are starting from scratch or porting an existing project.

segment.source: Writing a new app
segment.target: Writing a new app

segment.source: With a clean slate, you have many options at your disposal, including:
segment.target: With a clean slate, you have many options at your disposal, including:

segment.source: Xamarin
segment.target: Xamarin

segment.source: With Xamarin, you can write your app in C#, have it run on Windows, and create native iOS apps too.
segment.target: With Xamarin, you can write your app in C#, have it run on Windows, and create native iOS apps too.

segment.source: Support for Xamarin is built into Visual Studio; just select the correct project type.
segment.target: Support for Xamarin is built into Visual Studio; just select the correct project type.

segment.source: Apache Cordova
segment.target: Apache Cordova

segment.source: If Javascript and HTML is more your thing, Apache Cordova (aka PhoneGap) will help you create cross-platform apps for iOS, Windows, and Android.
segment.target: If Javascript and HTML is more your thing, Apache Cordova (aka PhoneGap) will help you create cross-platform apps for iOS, Windows, and Android.

segment.source: This project type is also built into Visual Studio.
segment.target: This project type is also built into Visual Studio.

segment.source: Game-engines
segment.target: Game-engines

segment.source: With tools like Unity3D and Unreal Engine at your disposal, you can write AAA-quality games for Windows and many other platforms, including iOS.
segment.target: With tools like Unity3D and Unreal Engine at your disposal, you can write AAA-quality games for Windows and many other platforms, including iOS.

segment.source: Unity supports C# scripting; Unreal uses C++.
segment.target: Unity supports C# scripting; Unreal uses C++.

segment.source: MonoGame
segment.target: MonoGame

segment.source: The spiritual successor to XNA.
segment.target: The spiritual successor to XNA.

segment.source: Now, it's an open-source cross-platform framework, which means you can write apps in C# for many platforms with support for physics engines, and 2D and 3D graphics.
segment.target: Now, it's an open-source cross-platform framework, which means you can write apps in C# for many platforms with support for physics engines, and 2D and 3D graphics.

segment.source: Adapting an existing app
segment.target: Adapting an existing app

segment.source: With an existing iOS app, your options are a little more limited.
segment.target: With an existing iOS app, your options are a little more limited.

segment.source: However, all is most certainly not lost.
segment.target: However, all is most certainly not lost.

segment.source: Windows Bridge for iOS
segment.target: Windows Bridge for iOS

segment.source: Also known as Project Islandwood, this is a still-in-development tool that can import Xcode projects directly into Visual Studio.
segment.target: Also known as Project Islandwood, this is a still-in-development tool that can import Xcode projects directly into Visual Studio.

segment.source: Objective-C code can be built and debugged from within Visual Studio.
segment.target: Objective-C code can be built and debugged from within Visual Studio.

segment.source: If your project makes use of libraries such as Cocos for graphics, you might find this a useful way to quickly port your app.
segment.target: If your project makes use of libraries such as Cocos for graphics, you might find this a useful way to quickly port your app.

segment.source: Repurpose your C++ code.
segment.target: Repurpose your C++ code.

segment.source: If your core business logic is written in C++, rather than Objective-C or Swift, you can often use this code with only minor changes in your project.
segment.target: If your core business logic is written in C++, rather than Objective-C or Swift, you can often use this code with only minor changes in your project.

segment.source: You can then use XAML to define your UI, as with other Windows apps, and call into the C++ code when necessary.
segment.target: You can then use XAML to define your UI, as with other Windows apps, and call into the C++ code when necessary.

segment.source: Use ANGLE to run OpenGL ES on Windows
segment.target: Use ANGLE to run OpenGL ES on Windows

segment.source: An intermediate step to porting your OpenGL ES 2.0 project is to use ANGLE.
segment.target: An intermediate step to porting your OpenGL ES 2.0 project is to use ANGLE.

segment.source: ANGLE allows you to run OpenGL ES content on Windows by translating OpenGL ES API calls to DirectX 11 API calls.
segment.target: ANGLE allows you to run OpenGL ES content on Windows by translating OpenGL ES API calls to DirectX 11 API calls.

segment.source: Other cross-platform authoring tools
segment.target: Other cross-platform authoring tools

segment.source: GameSalad
segment.target: GameSalad

segment.source: A game authoring environment.
segment.target: A game authoring environment.

segment.source: Construct 2
segment.target: Construct 2

segment.source: A game authoring environment.
segment.target: A game authoring environment.

segment.source: Titanium Studio
segment.target: Titanium Studio

segment.source: A cross-platform authoring environment.
segment.target: A cross-platform authoring environment.

segment.source: Cocos2D-x
segment.target: Cocos2D-x

segment.source: A cross-platform code library for sprite handling and physics modeling.
segment.target: A cross-platform code library for sprite handling and physics modeling.

segment.source: Impact.js
segment.target: Impact.js

segment.source: An HTML based game library.
segment.target: An HTML based game library.

segment.source: Marmalade
segment.target: Marmalade

segment.source: A cross-platform SDK.
segment.target: A cross-platform SDK.

segment.source: OpenFL
segment.target: OpenFL

segment.source: A cross-platform development tool.
segment.target: A cross-platform development tool.

segment.source: GameMaker
segment.target: GameMaker

segment.source: An authoring environment specifically for games.
segment.target: An authoring environment specifically for games.

segment.source: PlayCanvas
segment.target: PlayCanvas

segment.source: An HTML based game development tool.
segment.target: An HTML based game development tool.
